item.description:
It was rainy today, so I decided to use my five-minute pomodoro breaks for push-ups and pull-ups.

My arms are getting a bit tired. üí™üèº

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 6 of 6
item.description: Some big goals for 2017, and some smaller ones too.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 5 of 6
item.description: My strategy for productivity: less social media, careful use of my time, and embracing the "pomodoro technique".
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 4 of 6
item.description: Olo is great; I helped build (almost from scratch) a large mobile web application; I did some open-source software; it was a good year professionally.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 3 of 6
item.description: On top of my 200,000 words of writing this year, I also published some 66 episodes and almost 20 hours of podcasting across four different shows.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 2 of 6
item.description: One of my goals for 2016 was to continue writing not only on this blog but in other outlets. I did a *lot* of writing this year, but relatively little of it is published. But here's a look at some of the numbers! (And they are large!)
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Part 1 of 6
item.description: Accidental 20-mile runs, walking pneumonia, gaining weight because of metabolic shifts, and other adventures in my "fitness" in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: 2016 in Review, Introduction
item.description: 2016 was a long, difficult, strange, sometimes wonderful and sometimes dreadful year for me. It was one of the most professionally and scholastically enjoyable and rewarding years of my life, and also one of the most exhausting. As I often do at years-end, I am taking stock publicly of what went well, what went poorly, and what I might do different in a variety of categories!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I have a problem and it is called: ‚ÄúI run further than I probably should given the heat and my readiness level.‚Äù üò≥

item.description: The day you accidentally run 20 miles, and then the day after‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I do not eat KFC often‚Äîbut every year, on the day I take my longest run of the year, I eat KFC, and I am glad. This year, today was that day. I just ate KFC. I am glad.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I accidentally ran 20 miles instead of just 16 today. üò¨ I am now profoundly uncomfortable in a number of surprising ways.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: Run With Me!
item.description:
I may have gone mad with power or something, but I launched another podcast today! Crazy, I know.

It‚Äôs both more and less crazy than it might sound, though. More, because of what the podcast is, and less, because of what the podcast is. So what is it?

Run ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: About to go for a run; there are 20mph winds right. Just like old times‚ÄîI‚Äôll be having flashbacks to running in Oklahoma (except with hills)!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: First day of true spring weather. Time to get the bike out and take a ride. Tri training season, here we come!
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: How I Became a (Relatively) Quick Runner
item.description: A few weeks ago, I ran the City of Oaks half marathon event for the third consecutive year. I finished at 1:24:58, which comes out to be about a 6:29/mile pace. I finished 20th overall, out of thousands of half-marathoners. If that seems fast to you ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: How I Became a Runner
item.description: Sometime in the last few years, I became ‚Äúthat runner guy.‚Äù It is no longer strange for me to introduce myself to someone new in the area we live, and hear them say, ‚ÄúHave I seen you running?‚Äù I smile and nod: ‚ÄúYep, that‚Äôs me.‚Äù And to be fair ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Ever since that 18-mile run earlier, I have been craving (and therefore drinking!) orange juice. Must be low on something or other.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I took an 18-mile run today‚Äîthe longest of my life so far. If you‚Äôd told me a half decade ago that I‚Äôd not only be doing this kind of thing but also feeling great afterward, I probably wouldn‚Äôt have believed you. But here we are.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: fleet once more
item.description:
Every time I step out to take a run,
¬†¬†¬†¬†it seems the clouds roll back,
¬†¬†¬†¬†the sun begins to shine,
¬†¬†¬†¬†intensifies its radiance and heat.
This makes for great discomfort, toil,
¬†¬†¬†¬†as sweat rolls down my brow
¬†¬†¬†¬†and heart rate climbs too quick,
¬†¬†¬†¬†requires me to slow and sweat the ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: A lovely rain storm started, so I thought I would take a run. Five minutes in, the rain stopped and then it was hot and sunny and muggy the rest of the time. Goodness.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I had forgotten both how good and how incredibly tired I feel after a hard fifteen mile run.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Tip for other runners out there: buy last year‚Äôs shoe model (on Ebay, Amazon, etc.). You‚Äôll pay way less.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: My ASICS Gel-Lyte33s lasted me over a thousand miles. The Gel-Lyte33 3s I got to replace them lasted less than 450 miles (more in line with normal expectations for running shoes). I wonder what changed between the models?
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: The uppers are coming off on both of my current pairs of ASICS running shoes. I guess it‚Äôs time to upgrade. $$$‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Trying to decide whether the kind of ‚Äúnot good‚Äù I‚Äôm feeling today is the kind that will get better or worse with exercise.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: I officially understand why people like triathlons. Cycling after running is just fine. Running after cycling is amazing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.title: The Long Race
item.description: It has been too long since I have written anything‚Äîtoo long not for my audience (small as it is), but for my soul. The last few weeks of class were of course even busier than the rest of the semester, courtesy of a couple major assignments I wrapped up ‚Ä¶
